questions.prompt: Which of the following is a proposition?
questions.explanation: A proposition is a declarative statement that is either true or false. "The Earth is flat" is a proposition (it's false, but it's still a proposition). Commands, questions, and statements with variables are not propositions.

questions.prompt: The negation of "It is raining" is "It is sunny."
questions.explanation: The negation of "It is raining" is "It is NOT raining." The weather could be cloudy, snowy, etc. without being sunny.

questions.prompt: What is the truth value of P ∧ Q when P is True and Q is False?
questions.explanation: The conjunction (AND) is only true when BOTH operands are true. Since Q is False, P ∧ Q is False.

questions.prompt: What is the truth value of P ∨ Q when P is False and Q is True?
questions.explanation: The disjunction (OR) is true when AT LEAST ONE operand is true. Since Q is True, P ∨ Q is True.

questions.prompt: The implication P → Q is only false when P is true and Q is false.
questions.explanation: The implication is false only when the hypothesis (P) is true but the conclusion (Q) is false. In all other cases, the implication is true.

questions.prompt: What is the negation of the proposition "It is raining AND it is cold"?
options: It is not raining AND it is cold
It is raining OR it is cold
It is not raining OR it is not cold
It is not raining AND it is not cold
questions.explanation: By De Morgan's Law, the negation of (P ∧ Q) is (¬P ∨ ¬Q). So "NOT (raining AND cold)" becomes "NOT raining OR NOT cold".

questions.prompt: The proposition (P → Q) is logically equivalent to (¬P ∨ Q).
questions.explanation: This is correct. The implication P → Q is true in all cases except when P is true and Q is false, which matches the truth table for ¬P ∨ Q.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is a tautology?
questions.explanation: P ∨ ¬P (the law of excluded middle) is always true regardless of the truth value of P. Either P is true or its negation is true.

questions.prompt: What is the contrapositive of "If it rains, then the ground is wet"?
options: If the ground is wet, then it rains
If the ground is not wet, then it does not rain
If it rains, then the ground is not wet
If it does not rain, then the ground is not wet
questions.explanation: The contrapositive of P → Q is ¬Q → ¬P. So "If it rains → ground is wet" becomes "If ground is NOT wet → it does NOT rain."

questions.prompt: The logical connective that is true only when exactly one of its operands is true is called ____.
questions.explanation: XOR (exclusive or) is true when exactly one of the operands is true, unlike OR which is also true when both are true.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is logically equivalent to ¬(P → Q)?
questions.explanation: The negation of an implication: ¬(P → Q) ≡ ¬(¬P ∨ Q) ≡ P ∧ ¬Q. "It is NOT the case that if P then Q" means "P is true AND Q is false."

questions.prompt: If P → Q and Q → R are both true, then P → R must also be true.
questions.explanation: This is the law of syllogism (transitivity of implication). If P implies Q and Q implies R, then P implies R.

questions.prompt: Which statement is equivalent to "p only if q"?
questions.explanation: "p only if q" means that p cannot be true unless q is also true, which is expressed as p → q.

questions.prompt: What is the result of applying De Morgan's Law to ¬(¬P ∨ Q)?
questions.explanation: ¬(¬P ∨ Q) = ¬(¬P) ∧ ¬Q = P ∧ ¬Q by De Morgan's Law and double negation.

questions.prompt: The biconditional P ↔ Q is equivalent to (P → Q) ∧ (Q → P).
questions.explanation: The biconditional "P if and only if Q" means both implications hold: P implies Q AND Q implies P.
